metadata.subject: Global Asset Allocation - The J.P. Morgan View: Do US elections change anything?
metadata.sender: J.P. Morgan Global Asset Allocation Team

relationships.description: J.P. Morgan providing investment analysis and recommendations on global asset allocation
Analysis of how political outcomes affect monetary policy decisions

transactions: Moving overweight from US to EM Asia equities
Moving credit overweight from US to Europe
Long positions in gold and base metals

analysis.purpose: To provide investment strategy guidance following the 2012 US presidential election outcome
analysis.significance: Shows how major financial institutions adjusted global investment strategies based on political outcomes and economic forecasts

notable_quotes: The equity market has priced out the Romney win scenario, but from these levels, our economic and market outlook and risks are unchanged.
We don't think an Obama victory truly changes the economic outlook, or risks, but it does eliminate the Romney hope that appeared to have been in market pricing.
As with sausage making, this process won't be pleasant to watch. It would be easier to return in several weeks when the final product is ready.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found - this is a standard financial market analysis report

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed - this is legitimate financial market analysis and investment strategy

public_knowledge.context: This type of market analysis from major investment banks is typically distributed to clients and represents standard financial industry commentary on political events and market impacts

analysis.summary: J.P. Morgan's global asset allocation team provides investment strategy guidance following the 2012 US presidential election, maintaining overweight positions in equities and credit while shifting exposure from US markets to EM Asia and Europe due to fiscal cliff concerns and improving Chinese economic data.
